_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The El Segundo Generating Station (ESGS) is a natural gas-fired electric generating station consisting of two operating units, Units 3 and 4, each rated at 335 megawatts (MW).  Each unit relies on an air pollution control device, known as a Selective Catalyic Reduction (SCR) device, which utilizes aqueous ammonia as the reducing agent in the reduction of nitogen oxides (NOx) to nitrogen gas that is exhausted from natural gas combustion process.

Aqueous ammonia is supplied to the SCR devices by the Aqueous Ammonia System.  This process is the only ARP covered process at ESGS and is subject to both federal ARP and California ARP Program 2 requirements.  The 29.4% aqueous ammonia is delivered to an underground storage tank (UST) by tank trucks operated by the chemical supplier.  Supply pumps at the UST transfer the material from the tank through a pipeline to the two SCR vaporization skids (one for each unit) and the Chemical Feed Station in Unit 3.  

The UST consists of a 20,000-gallon, double-walled, FRP clad, carbon steel tank designed to the ASME Unfired Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII.  It is equipped with liquid level and overfill prevention, pressure relief valves, vacuum breaker, flame arrestor, temperature and pressure reference level indicators.  A continuous leak detection system is provided with interstitial liquid sensors at each end of the tank bottom and local vapor detectors that are continuously monitored in the Control Room.  The UST contains three supply pumps (one active and two standby, each with a maximum capacity of 7 gallons per minute) that transfer the aqeous ammonia into the pipeline.  

The pipeline consists of a stainless steel piping at a maximum internal diameter of 2 inches, designed to ANSI B31.1, with pressure relief valves, flow solenoid shut-off valves, temperature and pressure reference level indicators.  The pipeline is predominately aboveground except for two portions that extend under the site roads.  Undergound piping is con

tained within carbon steel piping with continuous liquid leak detection monitoring of the annular space.

The aqueous ammonia is delivered to the two SCR vaporization skids where it passes through a duplex strainer and a shutoff valve before splitting into two separate lines that each feed one of two vaporizors on each SCR skid.  Hot boiler (dilution) air is directed through the two vaporizors where atomizing nozzles spray the aquesous ammonia into the hot boiler air which evaporates the ammonia.  The air/ammonia mixture is then injected into the flue gas of each unit's boiler that then flows into SCR reactor.  The SCR reactor contains a horizontal flow catalyst bed where the NOx reacts with ammonia to form inert nitrogen gas and water that are exhausted through the stacks.

The Chemical Feed System is operated manually on a batch basis.  An operator must be present to hold open the dead-man valve on the aqueous ammonia supply line during filling of the transparent acrylic metering cylinder.  Once filled, the operator releases the dead-man valve which springs closed.  The operator then opens one of the two hand gate valves to gravity feed the aqeuous ammonia into either the Unit 3 or Unit 4 mix tanks that contain dilution water (two 50 gallon vertical carbon steel tanks).  The resulting mixture from the mix tanks is then pumped into the suction boiler feed pump and/or discharge condensate pump.  

The aqueous ammonia storage tank is filled via the chemical supplier's 6,000 gallon tanker truck with deliveries scheduled at regular intervals based on ammonia consumption.  Operating procedures require an ESGS operator to be present throughout the unloading process and be ready to respond to concerns.    

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies.  ESGS has had an active hazardous materials management and accident prevention program that emphas safety and good management practices in all of its activities.  An offsite consequence analysis (OCA) was p

erformed and considered for the implementation of the accident prevention program and the emergency planning.  All activities are conducted in accordance with detailed standard operating procedures, active participation by management, line and contractor employees.

The accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
*  Maintenance of a management system specific to the RMP to oversee its effective development.
*  Use of process and safety equipment designed and maintained in accordance with applicable requirements and industry standards.
*  Maintenance of process descriptions, safety information, equipment specifications and manuals, drawings and related information onsite.
*  Implementation of a management of change process to thoroughly evaluate proposed changes to the Aqueous Ammonia System for potential impacts on safety or release prevention.
*  Routine preventative maintenance of equipment in accordance with applicable requirements and manufacturer manuals.
*  Routinely conducting process hazard analyses to review potential hazards associated with Aqueous Ammonia System to ensure that it is designed, constructed, and operated in a safe manner, including under hypothetical hazard events (e.g., equipment malfunction, human error, external events, etc.).  
*  Developing and routinely updating operating procedures that provide clear instruction to operators, maintenance personnel, and contractors for safely and effectively conducting tasks and activities.  
*  Maintenance of a comprehensive training program designed to ensure competency for personnel with responsibility for operating and maintenance of the Aqueous Ammonia System.  The training approach is a combination of both on-the-job training and classroom training to familiarize workers with the equipment, operating procedures and requirements.  Plant managers, supervision, and experienced operators of the Aqueous Ammonia System provide on-the-job training to ensure that only wo

rkers who have the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties and responsibilities as provided in the operating procedures perform work on the Aqueous Ammonia System.  

Compliance audits are completed at least every 3 years to verify that the procedures and practices are adequately being implemented.

There have been no accidental releases from the aqueous ammonia system in the past 5 years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known deaths, injuries, evacuations sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

ESGS maintains an Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan that is coordinated with local responders.  The core elements of the emergency response program include the following:
*  Specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of ammonia
*  Procedures to notify local and public agencies including the El Segundo Fire Department, the California Emergency Management Agency, and the National Response Center
*  Contact and location for emergency medical care
*  Information regarding the training of employees on responses to releases
*  A list of Federal and state requirements the facility is subject

Planned changes to improve safety include enhancing the information in operating procedures and training and enhancing the effectiveness of the management of change process.
